From: "Mathieu Gervais" <egoine_@...>

>I found myself writing pages to be testable by marking up interesting bits
of the page so I could find them. For example, if I included my error
>messages in <span id="errorMessage"> I could just write
>findSpansWithId("errorMessage").

I use exactly this technique. I use the excellent HTTPUnit package. (with
response.getTableWithId() ).

mathieu

----- Original Message -----
From: Steve Freeman
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, July 20, 2001 4:58 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] How to write Test Cases for Jsp's


I did something similar with WebL (a.k.a. Compaq Web Language) which is very
pleasant to work with but seems to be dying.

I found myself writing pages to be testable by marking up interesting bits
of the page so I could find them. For example, if I included my error
messages in <span id="errorMessage"> I could just write
findSpansWithId("errorMessage"). Of course, I discovered that coding for
testability made other things easy, as everything was ready for using
stylesheets without much extra preparation.

Steve

From: "Shane Duan" <sduan@...>
> I worked in WebMacro before and the lead there (actually the boss) seted
up
> an testing environment that can generate the output text of a WebMacro
page.
> Then we use a Java-Perl tool to parse the resulting string.  For example,
if
> we want to assert title, we just ask for a mach of the regular expression
> (*<html>*<head>*<title>[Title Text]</title>*</head>*</html>).
>
> We ended up (through refactoring) having a customized test case that can
do
> things like assertTitle, assertCheckBoxName, assertCheckBoxSelected.  (Off
> the thread, what we have built through testing and refactoring was so
> comprehensive and efficient that I was totoally converted into XP. :)  )
